The Tiger Multitasking languageIntroduction

Introduction

The Tiger Multitasking computer modules as well as the Tiger Multitasking language and development interface have been developed and coordinated by Wilke Technology. Applications with Tiger Multitasking computer modules are generated with a comprehensive development environment under Windows. The language used, Tiger Multitasking, is tailored to the requirements of a process computer. Repetitive tasks are implemented as complete instructions or functions, device drivers and example applications accelerate the software development process.

Everything takes place in this development environment, from the program input, troubleshooting right through to programming the module. Tiger Multitasking programs have the extension ‘.TIG’. The examples listed in this manual can be found in the ‘EXAMPLE’ subdirectory of the TIGER directory. Most of the examples can be run immediately, are complete programs and can be directly loaded, compiled, transferred and executed in a Tiger Multitasking module.

The Tiger Multitasking languageStructure of Tiger Multitasking programs

Structure of Tiger Multitasking programs

Since Tiger Multitasking is a multitasking program, an application can contain more than just one program in the conventional sense. The individual programs are hereby called tasks. Each task is initially a completely independent program that can be started and stopped at random. Tasks can either carry out independent jobs or work together on a larger job. Tasks can affect each other and communicate with one another. In the simplest case, a task consists of only a few instructions, though this can be expanded to include thousands of lines of code.

 

 

Tiger Multitasking V6.03 | Support :support@wilke.de | Tel: +49 2405 408 55-0 | Wilke Technology GmbH | Aachen | Germany 

The Tiger Multitasking languageNotation

Notation

Tiger Multitasking source programs consist of ASCII text and are generated with the development editor interface. Similarly, purely ASCII texts can also be imported from other editors.

No differentiation is made between upper and lower case for symbols and keywords. You can use your own notation here and, for example with very long names, use both upper and lower case for better legibility: “DriveXWheel” = DRIVEXWHEEL. Exceptions are listed in the descriptions of the instructions.

Instructions consisting of two words can also be written with ‘_’ instead of a space (RUN TASK = RUN_TASK). Instructions and arguments are to be separated by at least one space or tab character. Each line may only contain 1 BASIC instruction with a comment. Lines that are too long can be split over a number of lines.

 

Tiger Multitasking V6.03 | Support :support@wilke.de | Tel: +49 2405 408 55-0 | Wilke Technology GmbH | Aachen | Germany 

The Tiger Multitasking languageExtra long lines

Extra long lines

A return or the comment sign signals the end of a BASIC instruction. Instructions which would require very long lines can be spread over a number of source-code lines with the ‘&’ sign. This often improves the legibility of a listing and permits very long instruction. The example here shows the string, which is required to generate large characters on the LC-display:
 

PRINT #1, '&

This text will be printed as one & ' comment

long line on the output device?

The Tiger Multitasking languageComments

Comments
A comment begins with an apostrophe and ends with the end of the line. Comment lines cannot be split with ‘&’.

The Tiger Multitasking languageThe MAIN task

 

The MAIN task

Every Tiger Multitasking application consists of at least one task. This is the MAIN task. Further tasks and subroutines can be added as necessary. The number of possible tasks and subroutines depends on the module type and its memory capacity.

After a Tiger module is activated or after a hardware reset, the MAIN task is automatically started (in RUN-Mode). If further tasks are to be run they should be started by a task (e.g. MAIN) that is already running. Any task can be started and stopped at random, except the MAIN task. All tasks can call subroutines at random. A subroutine can also be used by a number of tasks simultaneously.

The task definition begins with the instruction TASK and the name of the task and ends with END. Variables defined within a task are only valid in that task. Global variables are defined outside of the MAIN task. Since the MAIN task is automatically executed as the first task after power-up, all initialization relevant to the project should be carried out at the beginning of the MAIN task. These include:

 

  • inclusion of important INCLUDE files
  • initialization of global variables (wherever required)
  • definition of FIFO buffers (always in MAIN task, yet still GLOBAL !)
  • installation of all required device drivers
  • setting of task priorities
  • start of other tasks

Device driver All required device drivers are included in the MAIN task. This is no longer possible in other tasks or subroutines. The program lines with the Multitasking instructions ‘INSTALL_DEVICE’ may only be executed once during the entire program run.

Global variables are declared outside the tasks.

Local variables Variables that are declared within a task or subroutine are local variables that can only be addressed within this scope of application. If local and global variables have the same name, the computer always selects the valid local variable in each case. The use of global variables in subroutines, as I/O parameters for subroutines and in the various tasks should be carefully planned. In a multi-task environment, it should also be remembered that other tasks may be using the same global variable at the same time.

FIFO buffer A special feature is that FIFO buffers are always by definition global, even though they are declared in the MAIN task.

 

 

As soon as task definitions and program codes become more complicated, we recommend an explicit declaration of each variable. This deliberate declaration provides maximum clarity on the type and scope of application of the variables and avoids errors, which could quickly arise through the use of incorrect variables and constants.

The compiler instruction: USER_VAR_STRICT tells the compiler to carry out a strict check of the variable declarations and use of constants. Undeclared symbols are then reported as errors.

The type declaration alone does not assign any value to a variable. This is important in systems with a battery backup for the RAM where variables are still assigned the same values (only global and task local variables) that they had before the power-down of the system. Local variables in subroutines can never be retained through a battery backup! If there is no protected RAM memory, the variables should be initialized accordingly.

Names in Tiger Multitasking programs can be up to 32 alphanumeric characters long. The underline character can be used. No differentiation is made between upper and lower case so that the notation can be chosen by the programmer in the way that he or she thinks best. The following methods have proven their worth when naming constants and variables - a list of ideas:

  • the bigger the scope of application of a variable, the more striking its name
  • do not use names of global variables for local variables
  • the variable type is identified by the 1st letter of its name, e.g.:
  • bReceive = BYTE
  • wCount = WORD
  • lAbsolut_X = LONG
  • rAngle_Speed4 = REAL
  • Long names should be enhanced: “MainDoorLock” or “main_door_lock” instead of MAINDOORLOCK

The inclusion of the variable declaration and device driver is followed by the further instructions in the task. The task definition ends with the instruction END. Tasks cannot be nested.

A typical program start for a small project could look something like this:

 

USER_VAR_STRICT							' variables must be declared!

STRING  Z0$ (7), Z1$ (7)				' global strings for
STRING  Z2$ (7), Z3$ (7)				' LCD cursor positions

#DEFINE LCD 1							' no. Of LCD device driver
#DEFINE ANALOG 4						' no. Of analog-in device driver

#INCLUDE KEYB_PP.INC					' subroutine and strings for
' US keyboard on Plug & Play Lab
TASK MAIN
  STRING CH$(1)							' character (local)
  LONG S, N								' select, loop (local)
  
  INSTALL DEVICE #LCD, "LCD1.TDD"		' LC-display
  INSTALL DEVICE #ANALOG, "ANALOG1.TDD" 	' analog-inputs (internal)
  
  CALL INIT_KEYB (LCD)					' US keyboard on Plug & Play Lab
  
  ' init values:
  Z0$ ="<1BH>A<00><0><F0H>"				' <- cursor on line-0
  Z1$ ="<1BH>A<00><1><F0H>"				' <- cursor on line-1
  Z2$ ="<1BH>A<00><2><F0H>"				' <- cursor on line-2
  Z3$ ="<1BH>A<00><3><F0H>"				' <- cursor on line-3
  
  SET_TASK_PRIO T2,123					' priority of TASK T2
  SET_TASK_PRIO T1,42					' priority of TASK T1
  RUN TASK T1							' start TASK T1
  RUN TASK T2							' start TASK T2
  
  ' program lines of the Task MAIN ...
END

 

The MAIN task is started after a reset. Other tasks have to be explicitly started (RUN_TASK).

Apart from the MAIN task, all tasks are equal and can in principle start, stop or terminate every other task.

The Tiger Multitasking languageSubroutines

 

Subroutines

Subroutines are a powerful tool to help structure program flows and make these more understandable. Subroutines contribute to an orthogonal and staggered programming thanks to their transfer of I/O parameters, local variables, unlimited length and the ability to be used by a number of tasks simultaneously.

Subroutines are structured similar to a task:

  • Start the subroutine by naming its name and listing the parameters in brackets
  • Declaration of local variables
  • Program code of the subroutine
  • END instruction signals the end of the subroutine code and at the same time has the same effect as a RETURN instruction.

Every subroutine definition begins with the instruction SUB and the name of the subroutine.

Up to 16 I/O parameters can then be defined. The keyword VAR signals that the values of the following parameters in this list can be altered in the subroutine. Parameters, which are only declared with BYTE, STRING, etc., are used simply as input parameters. They cannot be assigned a new value in the subroutine.

This is followed by a declaration of the local variables. Variables that are declared within a subroutine are always local. A new set of local variables is generated each time a subroutine is called. This ensures that no conflicts arise between the variables even if the subroutine is being used simultaneously by a number of tasks or in the event of a recursive call.

 

SUB TEST ( BYTE HIGH, WIDE; VAR STRING CHAR$.)
 BYTE J                    ' local variables
 CHAR$ = "A"                    ' CHAR$ can be changed
'...
END
  Z3$ ="<1BH>A<00><3><F0H>"				' <- cursor on line-3
  
  SET_TASK_PRIO T2,123					' priority of TASK T2
  SET_TASK_PRIO T1,42					' priority of TASK T1
  RUN TASK T1							' start TASK T1
  RUN TASK T2							' start TASK T2
  
  ' program lines of the Task MAIN ...
END

 

 

This is followed by the subroutine instructions. The size of the subroutine is only restricted by the available memory. The subroutine definition ends with the instruction END, which both indicates the end of the subroutine code and has the same effect as the RETURN instruction.

The following example shows a small multitasking program with two tasks and one subroutine. The MAIN task counts up the global indexed variable “Count” in an empty FOR-loop, while the 2nd task shows the current value of the indexed variable once every second on the LC-display. The “Second” task is terminated after 10 seconds and then shows the value: “Loops / s” an.

 

Program example:

 

 

'----------------------------------------------------------
' Name: 2TASKS.TIG
'----------------------------------------------------------
LONG Count                    		' global varTASK MAIN
' begin task MAIN
' install LCD-driver (BASIC-Tiger)
INSTALL DEVICE #1, "LCD1.TDD"
' install LCD-driver (TINY-Tiger)
' INSTALL DEVICE #1, "LCD1.TDD", 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 80h, 8
RUN TASK Second          		 	' start task Second
FOR Count = 0 TO 9999999       		' begin empty FOR-loop
NEXT                    			' end empty FOR-loop
END                    				' end task MAIN
'----------------------------------------------------------
' task Second shows var "Count" once per second on LC-display
'----------------------------------------------------------
TASK Second                			' begin task Second
  LOOP 10                				' do 10 loops
    PRINT #1, "<1>sum loops :"; Count  ' show global var Count
    WAIT DURATION 1000           		' wait for 1 sec
  ENDLOOP                				' next loop
  CALL Ready (10)            			' call subroutine
END                    				' end task Second
'----------------------------------------------------------
' Subroutine: show calculated value "loops per second"
'----------------------------------------------------------
SUB Ready (BYTE d)           	 	' begin subroutine Ready
  PRINT #1,"Loops / s:"; Count / d    ' d is local, Count is global
END                    				' end subroutine Readyc

 

 

Tiger Multitasking V6.03 | Support :support@wilke.de | Tel: +49 2405 408 55-0 | Wilke Technology GmbH | Aachen | Germany 

The Tiger Multitasking languageData types

Data types

Tiger Multitasking provides the following data types:

 

 

Numbers always begin with a digit and are written decimal, octal, hexadecimal, binary, with the unit Mega (1048576) or Kilo (1024).

Also, the scientific notation is possible. The E or e separates mantissa from exponent.

 

 

 

 

BYTE

Byte constants and variables are within the range 0<=x<=255.

Byte values are always positive and occupy 1 Byte of storage location.

WORD

Word constants and variables are within the range 0<=x<=65535.

Word values are always positive and occupy 2 Bytes of storage location.

LONG

Long constants and variables are within the range

-2.147.483.648<=x<=2.147.483.647.

Long values always have an operational sign and occupy 4 Bytes of storage location.

REAL

Real constants and variables always have an operational sign and are within the range 4.19*10-307 to 1.67*10308 (double precision). Between 15 and 16 relevant positions are calculated. Real values occupy 8 Bytes of storage location.

Calculations with REAL figures take longer than calculations with BYTE, WORD or LONG figures. A calculation is always completed before another task is assigned CPU time. This should be remembered when another task requires short reaction times.

 

 

In the case of instructions and calculations relating to the runtime of the program, automatic type conversions are normally carried out. When converting a LONG variable to a WORD or BYTE variable or a WORD variable to a BYTE variable, the value may be falsified if the numerical value is too large for the variable or if the operational sign is lost for WORD and BYTE variables.

During compilation the compiler permits such assignments and truncates the variable accordingly: WORD 123h becomes the Byte variable 23h. LONG -15 (FFFFFFEBh) becomes the BYTE variable 0EBh.

Tiger Multitasking uses Real in the IEEE754-64Bit-Float-Format.


 

 

Tiger Multitasking does not support any denormalized REAL numbers.
 

STRING

Strings can contain 0 to 32765 characters. Any character code 000FFh is allowed. String variable names always end with ‘$’. String constants are placed in quotation marks. A ’%’ sign after the string interprets its contents as a sequence of hexadecimal codes. The codes may be written more legibly through separation by a space character. Strings can be entered in a special form especially for pixel graphics: every ‘0’-Bit is entered as a dot and every ‘1’-Bit as ‘*’. The string is identified by a ‘b’ or ‘B’ following directly after the closing quotation marks.

Code information in String constants may take the form of hex or decimal code. This means that non-printable characters can be included in the string. Various notations are possible.

The ‘<’ sign is entered in the string as follows: ‘<<’.

 

Examples:

The standard length of a string is 64 Bytes. The size of individual strings can be determined by specifying their size in brackets, e.g. so as to use storage space on the stack sparingly:

A$(5)

Strings which are to be larger than 64 Bytes must be declared accordingly:

B$(8000)

Use the compiler instruction

USER_STRING_SIZE Sample

to set the standard length of a string to a different value (value=1 to 32765).

 

DATALABEL

DATALABELs can be set in order to access data in flash memory. Datalabels must be declared before first usage, even if USER_VAR_STRICT has not been used. Datalabels mark locations in the User Flash and enable symbolic names for flash areas. Datalabels end with 2 colons and thus are distinguished from usual labels.

Datalabels will always be declared or defined in a task or subroutine. It is not necessary to call the task or subroutine. The datalabel is always global.

 

DATALABEL DL1        ' declare
DL1::           	 ' set datalabel
DATA LONG 1234567    ' corresponding value

 

Program example:

 

'----------------------------------------------------------
' Name: DATALABL.TIG
'----------------------------------------------------------
TASK MAIN              							' begin task MAIN
  STRING A$                						' var of type STRING
  DATALABEL DL0, DL1, DL2       		 			' declare data labels
  ' install LCD-driver (BASIC-Tiger)
  INSTALL DEVICE #1, "LCD1.TDD"
  ' install LCD-driver (TINY-Tiger)
  ' INSTALL DEVICE #LCD, "LCD1.TDD", 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 80h, 8
  DL0::                    						' set data label DL0
  DATA BYTE "Bytes at DL0"        				' put string into FLASH
  DL1::                    						' set data label DL1
  DATA FILE "C:\TIGERBAS\EXAMPLES\FLASHTXT.TXT" 	' file into FLASH
  DL2::                    						' data label DL2 as reference
  PEEK_FLASH DL0, A$, DL1 - DL0        			' read A$ from FLASH pos. DL0
  PRINT #1, A$                					' output to LCD
  PEEK_FLASH DL1, A$, DL2 - DL1        			' read A$ from FLASH pos. DL1
  PRINT #1, A$;                					' output to LCD
END                    							' end task MAIN

 

Naming position in flash

DATALABEL marks a position in flash in a similar way like ‘goto labels’ in the source file. Symbolic names can be used instead of addresses in the user flash area. Datalables end with two colons.

The Tiger Multitasking languageCompound data types

 

Compound data types

Compound variables containing a number of simple variables can be constructed from the simple data types

Tiger Multitasking recognizes the following compound data types:

  • ARRAY
  • FIFO

 

ARRAY

Declaration of an array:

ARRAY Name ( Number1 [,Number2, ... , Number8] ) OF Type

An array is a variable field with a series of variables of the simple data type BYTE, WORD, LONG, REAL or STRINGS. Please note that STRINGS is plural.

The same rules apply when naming an array as apply for a simple variable.

Numberx specifies the possible number of elements in this dimension that an array can contain.

When using the array, Numberx is replaced by the index number of the array element. The index is thus a pointer to the element.

The array index starts with 0.

 

Tiger Multitasking supports arrays with 1 to 8 dimensions.

The storage location required for an array is calculated using the number of elements stored, which is given by the x space value of an array element.

The available RAM storage location determines the maximum size of an array.

 

'-----------------------------------------------------------
' Name: ARRAY.TIG
'-----------------------------------------------------------
ARRAY M$(12,2) OF STRINGS    		' global array with 2 x 12
' entries (2 dimensions)
TASK MAIN            				' begin task MAIN
  ' install LCD-driver (BASIC-Tiger)
  INSTALL DEVICE #1, "LCD1.TDD"
  ' install LCD-driver (TINY-Tiger)
  ' INSTALL DEVICE #1, "LCD1.TDD", 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 80h, 8
  CALL INIT_ARRAY        			' call subroutine
  FOR J = 0 TO 1        			' index J runs from 0 to 1
    FOR I = 0 TO 11        			' index I runs from 0 to 11
      PRINT #1, M$(I,J)    			' output of entry I,J
      WAIT_DURATION 500    			' wait 500 ms
    NEXT                			' next index I
  NEXT                				' next index J
END               			 		' end task MAIN
'----------------------------------------------------------
' Subroutine INIT_ARRAY fills array M$ with "values"
'----------------------------------------------------------
SUB INIT_ARRAY ()        ' begin subroutine
  M$(0,0) = "Januar   "
  M$(1,0) = "Februar  "
  M$(2,0) = "Maerz    "
  M$(3,0) = "April    "
  M$(4,0) = "Mai      "
  M$(5,0) = "Juni     "
  M$(6,0) = "Juli     "
  M$(7,0) = "August   "
  M$(8,0) = "September"
  M$(9,0) = "Oktober  "
  M$(10,0) = "November "
  M$(11,0) = "Dezember "
  M$(0,1) = "january  "
  M$(1,1) = "february "
  M$(2,1) = "march    "
  M$(3,1) = "april    "
  M$(4,1) = "may      "
  M$(5,1) = "june     "
  M$(6,1) = "july     "
  M$(7,1) = "august   "
  M$(8,1) = "september"
  M$(9,1) = "october  "
  M$(10,1) = "november "
  M$(11,1) = "december "
END

 

Declaration of a FIFO buffer:

FIFO Name ( Number ) OF Type

FIFO buffers are data queue buffers. The first data values written into the buffer are also the first to be read out (First-In-First-Out-Buffer). For example, FIFOs can compensate for different data speeds between the data source and buffers (e.g. input/output buffers).

An interesting instruction to filter noisy and distorted measured values is INTEGRAL_FIFO. A fast, continuous short-term integration can be easily carried out with this instruction via a configurable ‘window’ width. An integration function that covers many cycles of a 50Hz signal can, for example, act as a low pass filter. ADC’s use oversampling and short-term integration to improve the conversion’s resolution.

FIFO buffers contain elements of the data type: BYTE, WORD or LONG.

(Number) specifies the number of elements that a FIFO buffer can accommodate in terms of 2n. If an invalid value is entered for Number, the compiler rounds this off to the next largest valid value.

Access to the elements is via special instructions:

 

The memory requirement is calculated by number of elements x space requirement of one element.

A FIFO buffer can be between 16 Byte and 4 Mbytes in size.

The available RAM storage space determines the maximum size of the FIFO buffer.

The Tiger Multitasking languageDeclare variable

 

 

 

Declare variable

Numeric variables and string variables do not have to be initially declared in Tiger Multitasking.

String variables are recognized by the compiler by the name ending ‘$’. These strings are automatically defined with the respective standard string length (64Bytes, or set with USER_STRING_SIZE).

Numeric variables are assigned either the LONG or REAL type depending on the context. This automatic type assignment is very helpful for small, quickly written programs. However, in large programs this can easily lead to errors because of incorrectly used variables, which are then difficult to detect. 

We recommend that you closely follow the following tip for larger projects:

The compiler instruction USER_ VAR_STRICT forces you to declare constants and variables. Undeclared variables, or incorrect variable types, found during transfer to the subroutines are reported as errors. Simply place the instruction USER_ VAR_STRICT at the beginning of your program.

A variable is still not initialized simply through its declaration. If the value of a variable is to be pre-set with a start value, it should be initialized accordingly.

Note: in battery applications with a battery backup, the unconditional Initialization of variables is senseless since the saved data contents will then be overwritten by variables.

 

Scope of application of variables

Variables which are declared outside a task or subroutine are global and can be read and modified by all tasks and subroutines. Variables that are declared within a task or subroutine are always local. Local variables of a task are static and are retained in systems with battery-backed RAMs after a power-down. This is also the case for global variables. Local variables of subroutines are always dynamic and cannot be retained by a battery backup.

Exception: FIFO buffers are always global although they must be declared within the MAIN task.

 

Variable names

Variable names consist of letters, digits and underline characters. The first character is always to be a letter. No differentiation is made between upper and lower case. The maximum length of a name is 32 characters. Names are made more legible through upper and lower case notation and underline characters.

Examples of variable names:

 

A
A2
KEY
key
motor_A
cylinder_3_ignition
result_coin_recognition

The Tiger Multitasking languageOperators

Operators

Mathematics

Boolean

Bit by bit

String

Further operations are carried out by functions, e.g. BITNOT, BIT_MIRR, square root (SQRT), exponentiation (EXP), sine and cosine functions, etc.

 

Priorities during calculation
 

The priorities during calculation range from the highest to the lowest priority:

  • Brackets, plus and minus signs
  • Operators *, /, BITAND, all shift operations
  • Operators +, -, BITOR, BITXOR
  • Relational operators <, >, <>, <=, >=
  • logical AND
  • logical OR, XOR

The Tiger Multitasking languagePreprocessor instructions

Preprocessor instructions

The preprocessor processes the program text before it is translated by the compiler. This can be used to produce less frequently used and less complicated notations. Constant number values are also normally substituted by a symbolic notation. The preprocessor can be used to integrate complicated files with standard definitions and subroutine libraries.

The preprocessor instructions begin with ‘#’.

 

#include

Integrates another file at this position.

Identical definitions or program sections that are required in various projects can thus be maintained in separate files. A project can be split into various smaller files that are then integrated from a main file.

A library of subroutines can be included as code is generated only for subroutines that are really needed.

 

Example:

#INCLUDE KEYB_PP.INC	' subroutine and strings for
' US keyboard on Plug & Play Lab

 

#define, #undef

#define Text1 Text2
#undef Text1

#define available from version 1.2
#undef available from version 5.4

Function:

  • #define substitutes all Text1 in the following code with Text2. Text1 ends with the first space character or tab character. Text1 is not substituted if in quotation marks or in connection with other letters. Text2 may also include space and tab characters and ends with the line end or comment sign. When used in an #ifdef instruction Text1 from this point on will give a true as result.
  • #undef ends the substitution of Text1 for the following code. When used in an #ifdef instruction Text1 from this point on will give a false as result.

 

Example for defines:

#define LCD 1				' all text "LCD" is replaced by "1"
#define CLS CALL CLEAR_LCD	' "CLS" is replaced by "CALL CLEAR_LCD"
#define RINT 2				' "RINT" -> "2" but not "PRINT" -> "P2"

 

Example for define / undef:

#define ErrCode 35       ' "ErrCode" is replaced by "35"
PRINT #1, ErrCode        ' The text "35" is printed
#undef ErrCode           ' "ErrCode" is no longer replaced
PRINT #1" ErrCode        ' "ErrCode" is now interpreted as variable
' and its value is printed

 

#define TIGER_1, #define TIGER_2 or #define TIGER_PLUS

#define TIGER_1 (or #define TIGER_2) (or #define TIGER_PLUS)

Available from version 5.3

Function: The symbolic constants “TIGER_1”, “TIGER_2” and “TIGER_PLUS” are automatically generated by the compiler and can be applied for managing the module-dependent branches of the source code. Creating these defines in your code may result in unwanted effects running your program and should thus be avoided.

Example for installing serial driver with different baud rates using Tiger 1, Tiger 2 or Tiger plus:

 

#ifdef TIGER_1
INSTALL_DEVICE #SER, "SER1B_K1.TDD", &
BD_38_400, DP_8N, JA, &        	    	' settings for SER0
BD_38_400, DP_8N, JA            	    ' settings for SER1
#else
INSTALL_DEVICE #SER, "SER1B_K1.TD2", &
BD_115_200, DP_8N, JA, &      	   	   ' settings for SER0
BD_115_200, DP_8N, JA            	   ' settings for SER1
#endif

INSTALL_DEVICE #SER, "SER1B_K1.TDP", &

#comment, #endcomment, #cm, #endcm

#comment (or #cm)
...
#endcomment (or #endcm)

Function: Marks the start respective the end of a comment area in the source text. Comments can also be nested.

The example shows the short form of the same commands:

#CM               	 ' start of comment
PRINT #1, "abc"    	 ' is not compiled (comment)
#ENDCM               ' end of comment

 

An example for nested comments:

#CM                		‘ start of comment (a)
PRINT #1, “abc“         ‘ not compiled, this is comment
#CM               		‘ start of comment (b)
WAIT_DURATION 1000      ‘ not compiled, this is comment
#ENCDM               	' end of comment (b)
PUT #2, “c“             ' not compiled, this is comment
#ENCDM               	' end of comment (a)

#ifdef, #ifndef, #elif, #else, #endif

#ifdef (or #ifndef)
…
#else (or #elif)
…
#endif

Available from version 5.01a

Function: Conditional compilation (in simplest form). Any word, that occurs on the left side of the #define instruction, is meant to be defined independently of “assigned” value and will be evaluated as true by #ifdef, #ifndef and #elif instructions.

Example:

#define DEBUG
…
#ifdef DEBUG
PRINT #LCD, DebugValue            ' output only if DEBUG is defined
#endif

 

#project_model

#project_model model_name

Available from version 4.6n (PM_FULL, PM_MIN)
Available from version 5.4 (PM_MEDIUM, PM_SMALL_W)

Function: With newer versions the Tiger Multitasking run time kernel is increasing in size as it contains more and more functions and instructions. Thus applications made for a certain module may get too large when compiled with a new run time kernel. With #project_model you can choose between the full run time kernel and smaller versions. The following project models are available:

  • PM_FULL: By default the compiler uses the full model containing all functions and instructions.
  • PM_MEDIUM: All functions and instructions are available except for all signal- and graphical functions.
  • PM_SMALL_W2: Contains all functions and instructions of PM_MEDIUM except for X-Port functions, ASC, BCD, PBCD, Bit Modify String, ANIB, INIB, Shift Stri, Scramble, Prime, Serial No, byte & bit mix & demix, I²C functions, I²CL functions, HDQ, 1-wire, FPGA, KEY_DIRECT, LOOKUP functions.
  • PM_SMALL_W: Contains all functions and instructions of PM_SMALL_W2 except for the PROGHASH function.
  • PM_MIN: The minimum compiler model does not support instructions and functions introduced since version 3.0. In the “BASIC-Tiger v5.0 Programming Manual”, section “Annotated Overview”, only instructions and functions included in the full project model are marked. The same identification can also be found on every page of the detailed description. Only instructions and function unmarked there are available in this model.
     
#project_model pm_medium

 

#project_path, #project_path_dyn

#project_path “[path]”
#project_path_dyn “[path]”

Available from version 5.3

Function: Paths to particular files (Includes, bitmaps, data etc.). The path can be set directly in the source code.

  • The “#project_path” can either be an absolute path or a relative path from the path of the project´s TIG file.
  • The “#project_path_dyn” is a relative path which expands the actual file path.

Several project paths and dynamical project paths may be set in a project.

Example:

Assuming your project’s TIG file is located in path “C:\MyProjects\Project01”, and in there we include “C:\MyProjects\Project01\Drivers\LCD\Panel1000.INC”.

Panel1000.INC:
 

#project_path "Definitions;..\IncludeFiles;E:\Data"
#project_path_dyn “Graphics;..\Sounds;"


The instruction #project_path would add the paths depending on the TIG file path and add the absolute path:

  • “C:\MyProjects\Projects01\Definitions”
  • “C:\MyProjects\IncludeFiles”
  • “E:\Data”

Additional to these, the instruction #project_path_dyn adds these directories depending on the actual file , here the Panel1000.INC file path:

  • “C:\MyProjects\Project01\Drivers\LCD\Graphics”
  • “C:\MyProjects\Project01\Drivers\Sounds”

All these paths are added to the list of searched paths for including files. (See also Preprocessor #include , IDE Directories

The Tiger Multitasking languageTiger Multitasking functions

Tiger Multitasking functions

Tiger Multitasking functions produce a scaler numeric functional value or a string result. Functions are always to the right of an equals sign (=) in expressions and instructions.

Functions whose name ends with a ‘$’-sign produce a string as a result. All other functions produce either INTEGER (BYTE, WORD, LONG) or REAL values.

Constants, variables or result values automatically undergo type conversion if this is necessary for the calculation or assignment of the result value. Unwanted type conversions always take up additional runtime and can affect the accuracy of the results. It has proven advantageous to try and stick to one type of variable in expressions.

Constants and expressions may normally also take the place of variables.

 

CR$ = CHR$ ( 13 )       	' string CR$ contains Return char.
Y = SIN ( X )            	' X and Y are REAL numbers
L_LONG = SIN ( X )        	' no sense, as SIN(X) is always < 1
A = ASC ( CR$ )            	' A gets value: ASCII code of CR$
L_LONG = R_REAL / W_WORD    ' automatic type conversion

The Tiger Multitasking languageCompiler instructions

Compiler instructions

Compiler instructions can be found at the start of the source text outside tasks and subroutine definitions. Compiler instructions are commands that affect the compilation sequence, though they do not generate directly executable code for the Tiger mutitasking module. Compiler instructions can be recognized by the prefix „USER“.

  • USER_FREQUENCY 
  • USER_STACK_SIZE
  • USER_STRING_SIZE 
  • USER_VAR_STRICT 
  • USER_SECURITY
  • SET_DATA_ADDR 
  • DATA 
  • USER_EPORT 
     

USER_FREQUENCY

USER_FREQUENCY SPEED_100

The Tiger plus CPU speed is adjusted with USER_FREQUENCY. Without this instruction, the default speed is SPEED_25. You are free to increase or decrease the CPU speed and adapt it to your application. Please refer the Tiger plus datasheet for typ. power consumption.

Options for USER_FREQUENCY:

 

USER_STACK_SIZE

USER_STACK_SIZE Value

Sets the stack to the size specified by Value.

Value is a constant.

 

The job of the stack is to dynamically provide storage location for subroutines. The stack manages local variables of the subroutine; the references to transferred parameters and the return address, for example.

If the stack is defined too small, it may overflow during program execution, which then leads to a serious malfunction in the program sequence. The corresponding task is stopped. An error message then appears in the Debug mode; no further display appears in the RUN mode. An important job in the development phase is thus to specify the maximum required stack size, by means of a worst-case analysis.

The total memory space (RAM) occupied by the stack is calculated from the number of tasks (including MAIN) multiplied by the stack size specified here. Example: an application with 7 tasks and a stack size of 2048 bytes thus occupies a total of 7 x 2048 = 14 336 bytes of RAM.

If you wish to save storage space, you should initially pay attention to the use of local variables. Use BYTE or WORD in place of LONG variables. Declare STRING variables explicitly with a maximum size so a provision will be made only for the number of bytes that will actually be used. Otherwise, the default string length will always be used (64Bytes, or set with USER_STRING_SIZE). Of course, in such situations sparing use should be made of local arrays. Whereas local variables are managed completely on the stack, I/O parameters only occupy a few bytes for their reference.

 

USER_STRING_SIZE

USER_STRING_SIZE Value

Sets the standard size of strings whose size is not explicitly declared to the size specified with Value.

Value is a constant.

The size of the string can be specified, e.g. to save stack space:

A$(5)

 

USER_VAR_STRICT

USER_VAR_STRICT

Demands the declaration of variables in the program („Declare variable").

 

USER_SECURITY

To protect your software in the Tiger mutitasking module, enter the following line in your source text:

USER_SECURITY “Codeword”

“Codeword” consists of 3 to 31 characters. The codeword is a combination of letters and numbers and begins with a letter. It is case-sensitive.

If a program which contains a USER_SECURITY line is loaded into the module, debugging or program deletion is only possible if the same codeword has been entered in the Security Code dialog of the Options menu. Make sure that you do not forget the codeword since the program in the module cannot be changed without this.

 

SET_DATA_ADDR

SET_DATA_ADDR: Sets address in Data-FLASH area

Function: Sets the start address for constant data in the Flash-memory.

Startadr is a constant of the type BYTE, WORD or LONG and determines the start address for subsequent DATA instructions.

The instruction SET_DATA_ADDR sets the start address from which constant data is permanently stored in the Flash-memory. Usual start address is 0.

 

Example:

'-----------------------------------------------------------
'Name: SET_DATA_ADDR.TIG
'-----------------------------------------------------------
TASK Main									'begin task MAIN
    'install LCD-driver (BASIC-Tiger)
    INSTALL DEVICE #1, "LCD1.TDD"
    'install LCD-driver (TINY-Tiger)
    'INSTALL DEVICE #1, "LCD1.TDD", 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 80h, 8
    SET_DATA_ADDR 40						'set starting address
    DATA &									'length:
    41, &									'1
    1234h									'2 order: 34 12
    SET_DATA_ADDR 50						'set starting address
    DATA "America"							'9 (with length byte)
    DataSize = 10 + 2 + LEN("America") 		'size of used FLASH
    USING "UH<2><2> 2.2.2.2.2"
    FOR I = 0 TO DataSize + 10				'show data as HEX and some
        PEEK_FLASH 40+I, B, 1				'more bytes
        PRINT_USING #1, B;
    NEXT
END 										'end task MAIN

 

DATA

DATA [Type] Constlist

Type 
determines the type of data BYTE, WORD, LONG, REAL, STRING, FILTER, or FILE and determines the values to be saved.

Tiger Plus 1: String length is a word (2 bytes)

Tiger Plus 2: String length is a long (4 bytes)

Constlist
 is a list of constants of the type BYTE, WORD, LONG, STRING, or FILE and determines the values to be saved.

 

The instruction DATA initializes a FLASH-sector with constants of various types.

The listed elements take up the same amount of space in the Flash as their size. For example the value 155 takes up one byte, the value 14234 2 bytes (WORD), 700000 requires 4 bytes (LONG), 24.5 takes up 8 bytes (REAL). In this case, character strings are saved with details of their length,e.g.:

“Hello” -> 05 00 ‘H’ ‘e’ ‘l’ ‘l’ ‘o’; a total of 7 bytes (Tiger1).

“Hello” -> 05 00 00 00 ‘H’ ‘e’ ‘l’ ‘l’ ‘o’; a total of 9 bytes (from Tiger Generation 2).

The list elements are divided by commas.
 

A fixed element size is specified by using ‘BYTE’, ‘WORD’, ‘LONG’ or ‘REAL’. This default value applies for the following list elements, until a semi-colon appears as a divider.
 

The list elements are saved according to the specification. For example, if 0ccddeeh is saved as BYTE, only 0eeh is written to the Flash. If character strings are saved as BYTE, details of the length will not be saved, e.g. “Hello” -> ‘H’ ‘e’ ‘l’ ‘l’ ‘o’; totaling 5 bytes.

The Type FILE reads a file from disk and writes its bytes into flash. This is useful especially for previously prepared sound data or graphic data.

The data saved in the FLASH can be read with the instruction PEEK_FLASH and additional data written with POKE_FLASH.

 

Example:

'-----------------------------------------------------------
'Name: DATA.TIG
'-----------------------------------------------------------
TASK Main             	   				'begin task MAIN
    'install LCD-driver (BASIC-Tiger)
    INSTALL DEVICE #1,    	"LCD1.TDD"
    'install LCD-driver (TINY-Tiger)
    'INSTALL DEVICE #1, "LCD1.TDD", 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 80h, 8
    SET_DATA_ADDR 40            	'set starting address
    DATA &             		   		'length:
    41, &              		  		'1
    1234h, &                		'2 order: 34 12
    "America"; &            		'9 (with length byte)
    BYTE 0eeeeeeh, &            	'1 BYTE only!
    0ff9h; &                		'1 BYTE only!
    BYTE "Process "            		'8 (without length byte)
    DataSize = 1+2+2+LEN("America")& 'size of FLASH area filled
    +1+1+LEN("Process ")     		'with the data
    USING "UH<2><2> 2.2.2.2.2"
    FOR I = 0 TO DataSize + 10    	'show data as HEX and some
        PEEK_FLASH 40+I, B, 1       'more bytes
        PRINT_USING #1, B;
    NEXT
END 								'end task MAIN

 

 

Insert data from a file into the flash memory

The Type FILE reads a file from disk and writes its bytes into flash one by one.

DATA FILE “Name” [, Offset, No. ]

Name is a variable, a constant or an expression of the type STRING and deter mines the file to be read. Drive and path are entered together with the filename or in the dialog Directory of the menu Options.

Offset is a variable, a constant or an expression of the type BYTE, WORD or LONG and determine the offset in the file, from where the bytes are read.

No. is a variable, a constant or an expression of the type BYTE, WORD or LONG and determine the number of bytes to be read.

The offset is 0 if no offset is given, and the whole file will be read if the number of bytes is not given. After FILE the files to be read can be listed.

DATA FILTER “Name”, “Filter”, Arguments

The Type FILTER reads a file from disk and writes its bytes into flash using a special filter. This is useful especially for previously prepared sound data or graphic data.

Name is a variable, a constant or an expression of the type STRING and deter mines the file to be read. Drive and path are entered together with the filename or in the dialog Directory of the menu Options.

Filter is a string determining the filter.

Arguments are different for each filter.

The following filters are implemented up to now:

 

Example for a source line including the file “ABC.BMP”:

DATA FILTER “ABC.BMP”, “GRAPHFLT”, 0

 

Example for a source line including the file “ABC.WAV”:

DATA FILTER “ABC.WAV”, “WAVEFLT”, 0, 8, 11025

 

Saving flash data from flash user area into a file

Using the command Read Flash Data from the menu Debug shows a dialog to enter the start- and end address as well as a file name. User data fro the flash will be transfered to a file on the hard disk.

Program example:

'-----------------------------------------------------------
'Name: DATAFILE.TIG
'-----------------------------------------------------------
TASK MAIN                					'begin task MAIN
    STRING A$                				'var of type STRING
    DATALABEL DL0, DL1, DL2  				'declare data labels
    'install LCD-driver (BASIC-Tiger)
    INSTALL DEVICE #1, "LCD1.TDD"
    'install LCD-driver (TINY-Tiger)
    'INSTALL DEVICE #LCD, "LCD1.TDD", 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 80h, 8
    DL0::               					'set data label DL0
    DATA BYTE "Bytes at DL0"    			'put string into FLASH
    DL1::                					'set data label DL1
    DATA FILE "C:\TIGERBAS\EXAMPLES\FLASHTXT.TXT" 'file into FLASH
    DL2::                					'data label DL2 as reference
    PEEK_FLASH DL0, A$, DL1 - DL0    		'read A$ from FLASH pos. DL0
    PRINT #1, A$            				'output to LCD
    PEEK_FLASH DL1, A$, DL2 - DL1    		'read A$ from FLASH pos. DL1
    PRINT #1, A$;            				'output to LCD
END 										'end task MAIN

USER_EPORT

Sets system parameters in the Tiger mutitasking module which relate to the control of the external ports. This instruction may also indirectly affect certain internal ports.

When using analog channels with the TINY-Tiger Economy, the eport system has to be disabled. The circuit points are connected with Port3 in the Economy module.

The eport system uses analog 0 (L33), analog 1 (L34), analog 2 (L35) as output. In PC mode, the pins are switched to output before the program will be started.

The Tiger Multitasking languageNumeric Functions Library

Numeric Functions Library

Introduction

The Numeric Functions Library contains a set of subroutines performing numerical calculations and conversions that are not directly implemented into the Tiger Multitasking language.

Each subroutine is called with a set of parameters, which either are the values to be converted or to calculate with or are return values containing the result(s) of the conversion/calculation.

In the following you will find a description of the single functions included in the library.

First of all, you have to include the library file:
 

#include NUMERIC_FUNCTIONS.INC

 

Do this at the beginning of your source code before task Main, like shown in the example programs. Now you are able to call the functions of the library as described in chapter “Subroutines”.

Exp_Real

call Exp_Real ( Err_Flag, Result, Base, Exponent )

Function: Calculates the result of an exponentiation x to the power of y (xy), where base x and exponent y are floating point (real).

Float2Real

call Float2Real ( FloatValue, RealValue )

Function: Converts a 32 bit floating point value that e.g. has been read from an external device to a 64 bit floating point value, so it can be displayed or used for further calculations in the Tiger. The 32 bit value has to be stored in a LONG variable.

32 bit floating point values are commonly known as single precision, 64 bit floating point values are referred to as double precision.

Examples of structure with value 3.1415926:

Single precision (32 bit)

Double precision (64 bit)

„REAL“ on Chapter 4

Real2Float

call Real2Float ( RealValue, FloatValue, Err_Flag )

Function: Converts a 64 bit floating point value to a 32 bit floating point value and stores it in a LONG variable. This value can then e.g. be sent to an external device that requires 32 bit floating point values for further processing.

32 bit floating point values are commonly known as single precision, 64 bit floating point values are referred to as double precision.

Examples of structure with value 3.1415926:

Single precision (32 bit)

Double precision (64 bit)

Round

call Round ( Value, Digits )

Function: Rounds a REAL value to a specific number of decimal places or significant figures.

 

If the number of digits is negative, the value will be rounded to significant figures, if it is positive or 0 it will be rounded to decimal places.

Example with value 4782.26374859:

 

BAM_Deg

call BAM_Deg ( BAM, Angle )

Function: Converts a binary angular measurement word (BAM) to an angle value between 0 and 360 degrees.

 

 

Binary angular measurement words (BAMs) are standardized binary words used to transfer angular measurements e.g. between shipboard tactical data system equipments. BAM data words are used to transfer quantities between digital equipments, from digital equipments to D/A converters, or from A/D converters to digital equipments.

BAM data words are specifically designed to indicate up angular values in binary form. The 16-bit word can indicate 360 degrees of angle in steps of 0.0055 degree. The LSB is equal to 0.0055 degree when set (ONE), while the MSB is equal to 180 degrees when set. When all 12 bits are set, a maximum angle of 359.9946 degrees is indicated. 0 or 360 degrees is indicated when all bits in the BAM data word are clear (Zeros).

 

Deg_BAM

call Deg_BAM ( Angle, BAM, Err_Flag )

Function: Converts an angle value between 0 and 360 degrees to a binary angular measurement word (BAM).

Binary angular measurement words (BAMs) are standardized binary words used to transfer angular measurements e.g. between shipboard tactical data system equipments. BAM data words are used to transfer quantities between digital equipments, from digital equipments to D/A converters, or from A/D converters to digital equipments.

BAM data words are specifically designed to indicate up angular values in binary form. The 16-bit word can indicate 360 degrees of angle in steps of 0.0055 degree. The LSB is equal to 0.0055 degree when set (ONE), while the MSB is equal to 180 degrees when set. When all 12 bits are set, a maximum angle of 359.9946 degrees is indicated. 0 or 360 degrees is indicated when all bits in the BAM data word are clear (Zeros).

The radian is used in virtually all mathematical work beyond simple practical geometry, due, for example, to the pleasing and “natural” properties that the trigonometric functions display when their arguments are in radians.

The Tiger Multitasking languageError handling during the runtime


Error handling during the runtime

Various errors can occur during the runtime:

  • Errors which are foreseen by the programmer (incorrect entries, buffer overflows, etc.)These errors are normally handled through corresponding inquiries in the program or through the explicit error handling of certain commands (ON_ERROR_CALL).
  • Errors which were not foreseen and which lead to data losses or incorrect values.
    These errors are ignored. The program should in any case continue to run (implicit error handling).
  • Errors that are fatal, the program cannot continue (stack overflow).
    Such errors stop the task in which the error has occurred. An error message appears in the Debug mode.

Explicit error handling

With certain instructions, the specification of an error handling routine is only possible for this one instruction (FIFO and Flash instructions).

Information on the error type and cause can be read from the SYSTEM variables using SYSVARx functions, SYSVAR$.
 

 

ON_ERROR_CALL Name

An error handling subroutine is called to initiate measures.

Error handling with ON_ERROR_CALL has the great advantage that the program continues to run normally after error handling.

ON_ERROR_GOTO Name

This leads to an abort. The program branches to a position specified by the label Name.

 

Implicit error handling

If implicit error handling is left entirely to the Tiger Multitasking system, this leads to data losses, incorrect values or a task stopping in the event of an error.

Implicit error handling can be controlled in every task so that a separate subroutine is called in the event of an error.

ON_ERRTASK_CALL Name

The subroutine Name is called if an error occurs outside the instructions with explicit error handling.

ON_ERRTASK_GOTO Name

The program branches to Name if an error occurs outside the instructions with explicit error handling.
